revision.text:
{{Infobox artifact |image = [[File:Bodhisattva dedicated by Bhikshu Bala at Sarnath 123 CE.jpg|250px]] |name = Bala Bodhisattva |image_caption =The Bala Bodhisattva dedicated in "the year 3 of [[Kanishka]]" (circa 123 CE) by "brother (''Bhikshu'') Bala". The right arm would have been raised in a salutation gesture. [[Sarnath Museum]]. |material = Red sandstone |size = about 205 cm |writing = |created = |period = 123 CE |place = [[Sarnath]], [[India]] |location = [[Sarnath Museum]], [[India]] | map = {{Location map| India | width = | float = center | border = | caption = | alt = | relief = yes | AlternativeMap = | overlay_image = | label = Findplace, [[Sarnath]], [[India]] | label_size = | position = left | background = | mark = | marksize = | link = | lat_deg = 25.38 | lon_deg =83.02 }} }} [[File:Bala Bodhisattva stone umbrella.jpg|thumb|Underside of the stone umbrella with designs, probably a [[Zodiac]]al pattern, similar to the fully Greek-derived zodiacal patterns of [[Medieval India]]Avatāraṇa: a Note on the Bodhisattva Image Dated in the Third Year of Kaniṣka in the Sārnāth Museum, by Giovanni Verardi, East and West, Vol. 35, No. 1/3 (September 1985), pp. 73 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/29756714 JSTOR].]] The '''Bala Bodhisattva''' is an ancient [[India]]n statue of a [[Bodhisattva]], found in 1904-1905 by German archaeologist [[F.O. Oertel]] (1862-1942) in [[Sarnath]], [[India]]. The statue has been decisive in matching the reign of [[Kanishka]] with contemporary sculptural style, especially the type of similar sculptures from Mathura, as its bears a dated inscription.Papers on the Date of Kaniṣka, Arthur Llewellyn Basham, Brill Archive, 1969, p.271 [https://books.google.com/books?id=ks4UAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA271] ==Inscription== The inscription on the Bodhisattva explains that it was dedicated by a "Brother" (''Bhikshu'') named Bala, in the "Year 3 of Kanishka". This allows to be a rather precise date on the sculptural style represented by the statue, as year 3 is thought to be approximately 123 CE. The inscription further states that [[Kanishka]] (who ruled from his capital in [[Mathura]]) had several [[satraps]] under his commands in order to rule his vast territory: the names of the [[Indo-Scythian]] [[Northern Satraps]] Mahakshatrapa ("Great Satrap") [[Kharapallana]] and the Kshatrapa ("Satrap") [[Vanaspara]] are mentioned as satraps for the eastern territories of Kanishka's empire. At the same time a "General Lala" and Satraps Vespasi and Liaka are mentioned as in charge of the north.Ancient Indian History and Civilization, Sailendra Nath Sen, New Age International, 1999, p.198 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Wk4_ICH_g1EC&pg=PA198]Foreign Influence on Ancient India, Krishna Chandra Sagar, Northern Book Centre, 1992 p.167 [https://books.google.com/books?id=0UA4rkm9MgkC&pg=PA167]Source: "A Catalogue of the Indian Coins in the British Museum. Andhras etc..." Rapson, p ciii [[File:Sarnath umbrella shaft inscription Kanishka Year 3.jpg|thumb|left|Complete inscription of Bhikshu Bala on the octagonal shaft of the umbrella.]] ;Inscription on the octagonal shaft There are altogether three inscriptions, the largest one being the inscription on the octagonal shaft of the umbrella. The octagonal shaft and its umbrella are visible in "Avatāraṇa: a Note on the Bodhisattva Image Dated in the Third Year of Kaniṣka in the Sārnāth Museum" by Giovanni Verardi."Avatāraṇa: a Note on the Bodhisattva Image Dated in the Third Year of Kaniṣka in the Sārnāth Museum, Giovanni Verardi East and West Vol. 35, No. 1/3 (September 1985), pp. 67-101" [https://www.jstor.org/stable/29756714 JSTOR.org] Original text:
1. maharafszcjjasya k[a]niskasya sam 3 he 3 di 20-2
2. etaye purvaye bhiksusya pusyavuddhisya saddhyevi-
3. harisya bhiksusya balasya tr[e]pi[ta]kasya
4. bodhisatvo chatrayasti ca pratisthapit[o]
5. baranasiye bhagavato ca[m]k[r?]ame saha mata-
6. pitihi saha upaddhyayaca[rye]hi saddhyevihari-
7. hi amtevasikehi ca saha buddhamitraye trepitika-
8. ye saha ksatra[pe]na vanasparena kharapall[a]-
9. nena ca saha ca[tu]hi parisahi sarvasatvanarn
10. hita[szc]sukharttham

Translation:
1. In the year 3 of the Great King Kaniska, [month] 3 of winter, day 22:
2-3. on this aforementioned [date], [as the gift] of the Monk Bala, Tripitaka Master and companion of the Monk Pusyavuddhi [= Pusyavrddhi or Pusyabuddhi?],
4. this Bodhisattva and umbrella-and-staff was established
5. in Varanasi, at the Lord’s promenade, together with [Bala’s] mother
6. and father, with his teachers and masters, his companions
7. and students, with the Tripitaka Master Buddhamitra,
8. with the Ksatrapa Vanaspara and Kharapallana,
9. and with the four communities,
10. for the welfare and happiness of all beings.
[https://archive.org/details/SalomonIndianEpigraphy Salomon p.271-272] [https://archive.org/stream/EpigraphiaIndica/Epigraphia_Indica#page/n227/mode/2up Epigraphia Indica p.173] ;Inscriptions on the base of the statue There are also two smaller inscriptions of similar content at the base of the statue:
At the front of the base of the statue:
"The gift of Friar Bala, a master of the Tripitaka, (namely an image of) the Bodhisattva, has been erected by the great satrap Kharapallana together with the satrap Vanashpara."[https://archive.org/stream/EpigraphiaIndica/Epigraphia_Indica#page/n235/mode/2up EI8 p.179]
At the back of the base of the statue:
"In the 3rd year of the Maharaja Kanishka, the 3rd (month) of winter, the 23rd day, on this (date specified as) above has (this gift) of Friar Bala, a master of the Tripitaka, (namely an image of) the Bodhisattva and an umbrella with a post, been erected."[https://archive.org/stream/EpigraphiaIndica/Epigraphia_Indica#page/n235/mode/2up EI8 p.179] ==Style== [[File:Bala Bodhisattva front and back views.jpg|thumb|Front and back views of the Bala Bodhisattva.]] The style of this statue is somewhat reminiscent of the earlier monumental [[Yaksha]] statues, usually dated to a few centuries earlier. On the other hand, despite other known instances of [[Hellenistic influence on Indian art]], very little if any such influence can be seen in this type of statue. Thus, they are quite different from the [[Greco-Buddhist art]] of [[Gandhara]].[http://www.tepotech.com/Art_Bulletin/192794JuneCoomaraswamyOriginoftheBuddhaImage.pdf Origin of the Buddha Image, June Coomaraswamy, p.300-301] The discovery was published in the "Archaeological Survey of India Annual Report for the Year 1904–1905", in an article by F.O. Oertel [https://archive.org/stream/in.ernet.dli.2015.207530/2015.207530.Archaeological-Survey#page/n141/mode/2up pp. 59–104]. The statue is now in the [[Sarnath Museum]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== * Avatāraṇa: a Note on the Bodhisattva Image Dated in the Third Year of Kaniṣka in the Sārnāth Museum, by Giovanni Verardi, East and West, Vol. 35, No. 1/3 (September 1985), pp. 67-101 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/29756714 JSTOR] ==See also== [[Indian art]]
[[Mathura art]] [[Category:Bodhisattvas]]

[[Image:One-Called-From-A-Distance Chippewa.jpg|thumb|right|200px|<center>"One Called From A Distance" (Medwewinind) of the White Earth Band, 1894. He is shown here wearing a Bandolier bag, with the strap across his chest.</center>]] A '''bandolier bag''' is a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] bag with a wide strap, often ornately decorated with beadwork, presented to represent honors given to a worthy man. Though bandolier bags are closely associated with the [[Anishinaabe]]g, they are not exclusively found among them as many bandolier bags have identifiable stylistic tribal and regional differences. A bandolier bag may be worn either across the shoulder to the side or in front like an apron. In the [[Anishinaabe language]], "bandolier bag(s)" is ''aazhooningwa'igan(ag)'', literally meaning "worn across the shoulder".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kstrom.net/isk/art/beads/bando1.html|title=Bandolier Exhibit Menu|last=Giese|first=Paula|date=1997|website=Native American Indian: Art, Culture, Education, History, Science|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-04-20}}</ref>
Bandolier bags are often incorrectly called [[medicine bag]]s.
<gallery> File:MedicineBagWabenoLoggingMuseum.jpg|A 1930 bandolier bag from Lake Superior Chippewa Indians, Lac Du Flambeau, Wisconsin, on at the Wabeno Logging Museum in Wabeno, Wisconsin, U.S. File:The Childrens Museum of Indianapolis - Bandolier bag - overall.jpg|Ojibwa bandolier bag overall, c. 1900, in the collection of [[The Children's Museum of Indianapolis]] File:The Childrens Museum of Indianapolis - Bandolier bag - detail.jpg|Ojibwa bandolier bag detail, c. 1900, in the collection of The Children's Museum of Indianapolis </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.kstrom.net/isk/mainmenu.html Native American Indian Resources Site]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=January 2010}} '''''Bhiksha''''' is food obtained by asking for [[alms]]. Bhiksha signifies a [[Hindu]] tradition of begging for alms with the purpose of self-effacement or ego-conquering.
Usually, bhiksha is the meal served to a ''[[sadhu]]'' or monk when that person visits a devout Hindu household. Occasionally, bhiksha has also referred to donations of gold, cattle, and even land, given to [[Brahmins]] in exchange for [[Karmkand]].
==References== {{Reflist}}{{Hinduism-stub}} [[Category:Hindu monasticism]] [[Category:Hindu traditions]] [[Category:Religious food and drink]] [[Category:Alms]]

revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=May 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox Political Party | colorcode = #C0C0C0 | name = Christian Democratic Party | logo = Christian_Democratic_Party_of_Australia_Logo.png | foundation = 1977 | dissolution = | headquarters = 1 Wentworth Street
Parramatta, NSW 2150 | ideology = [[Conservatism in Australia|Conservatism]]
[[Social conservatism]]
[[Christian democracy]]
[[Christian right]]{{cite web|url=http://www.afr.com/news/politics/national/mike-baird-accidental-premier-20150129-131ici|quote=The group also has links to the Christian Right, particularly the Christian Democratic Party of Reverend Fred Nile|title=The Q Society|year=2012}} | position = [[Right-wing politics|Right-wing]] | international = | seats1_title = [[NSW Legislative Council]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|2|42|hex=#7F007F}} | colours = {{Color box|orange|border=darkgray}} [[Orange (color)|Orange]] (official)
{{Color box|#7F007F|border=darkgray}} [[Purple]] (customary) | website = [http://www.cdp.org.au/ www.cdp.org.au] | country = Australia |leader2_title=NSW State President|leader2_name=[[Ross Clifford]]|leader3_title=NSW Deputy President|leader3_name=[[Fred Nile]]|leader4_title=NSW State Director|leader4_name=Craig Hall|leader5_title=Christian Youth President|leader5_name=Samraat Joshua Grewal}} The '''Christian Democratic Party''' ('''CDP''') is a [[Social conservatism|socially conservative]] political party in [[Australia]]. It was founded by a group of concerned Christian ministers in the State of NSW, who had [[Fred Nile]], a [[Fellowship of Congregational Churches|Congregational Church]] minister, run as their Upper House Candidate in the NSW State election. Fred Nile, commonly refers to himself as the party's founder, however the Party states that it was founded by concerned Australian ministers.https://www.cdp.org.au/about-the-cdp/ The party was established in 1977 under the name '''Call to Australia''', which it used until 1998. It is primarily active in [[New South Wales]], and since the [[New South Wales state election, 1981|1981 state election]] has had at least one member in the [[New South Wales Legislative Council]], often holding or sharing the [[balance of power (parliament)|balance of power]]. The Christian Democrats have never elected anyone to [[Parliament of Australia|federal parliament]], although [[John Bradford (Australian politician)|John Bradford]] briefly sat with the party in the [[Australian House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] after defecting from the [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal Party]] prior to the [[Australian federal election, 1998|1998 election]]. == Leadership == The [[Fred Nile|Rev Hon Fred Nile]], is the Federal President of the Christian Democratic Party (The Federal party currently lacks a constitution and a Board) and he is the NSW Deputy President. [[Ross Clifford]] is NSW State President of the Christian Democratic Party.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cdp.org.au/team/leadership-group/|title=Leadership Group ⋆ Christian Democratic Party|work=Christian Democratic Party|access-date=2018-06-15|language=en-US}} Craig Hall, is the NSW State Director; the organizational leader of the Party and by extension exercises authority over the Party activities in all states.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdp.org.au/?s=craig+hall|title=You searched for craig hall ⋆ Christian Democratic Party|website=Christian Democratic Party|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-15}} The youth wing of the CDP "Christian Youth" is headed by Samraat Joshua Grewal as it's President.https://www.cdp.org.au/team/young-cdp/ ==Formation== Originally established as the "Call to Australia Party" in 1977, the Party was founded by a group of concerned Christian Ministers who had Fred Nile run as their candidate.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cdp.org.au/about-the-cdp/|title=About ⋆ Christian Democratic Party|work=Christian Democratic Party|access-date=2018-06-15|language=en-US}} The Party name change to "Christian Democratic Party" was a suggestion from an executive of [[Hillsong Church]]. These groups had sought to mobilise [[Conservatism in Australia|conservative]] and evangelical [[Protestants]] as an electoral force. Nile was elected to the [[New South Wales Legislative Council|Legislative Council]] in 1981, and the party has managed to see a candidate elected at every subsequent New South Wales state election to date.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cdp.org.au/about-the-cdp/|title=About ⋆ Christian Democratic Party|work=Christian Democratic Party|access-date=2017-08-06|language=en-US}} ==Policies== The Christian Democrats exists to support Christian representation in every level of government – Federal, State and Local - and to promote "ethical values based on...Christian values".{{cite web|url=http://www.cdp.org.au/ |title=Welcome to The Christian Democratic Party |publisher=The Christian Democratic Party |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.cdp.org.au/about-the-cdp/|title=About ⋆ Christian Democratic Party|work=Christian Democratic Party|access-date=2018-05-08|language=en-US}} The party are supportive of family values (including traditional marriage), freedom of speech, protective of children and their rights including those of unborn children, and policies that are protective of established Australian values and systems, inclusive of a requirement that immigrants to Australia demonstrate a desire to learn English.{{cite web|url=http://www.cdp.org.au/what-is-cdp.html |title=What is CDP? |publisher=The Christian Democratic Party |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110218130912/http://www.cdp.org.au/what-is-cdp.html |archivedate=18 February 2011 |df=dmy }}{{Cite news|url=http://www.cdp.org.au/about-the-cdp/principles-of-the-cdp/|title=Principles of the CDP ⋆ Christian Democratic Party|work=Christian Democratic Party|access-date=2017-08-06|language=en-US}} They are opposed to both abortion{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/warning-that-australian-christians-party-is-a-rebranded-christian-democratic-party-for-federal-election/story-fnho52ip-1226648634383|title=Warning that Australian Christians party is a 'rebranded' Christian Democratic Party for Federal Election|author=James Elton-Pym|date=23 May 2013|work=News.com.au}} and euthanasia as well as pornography, drug decriminalisation and sharia law.{{cite web|url=http://www.cdp.org.au/federal-policies/pro-life-issues.html|title=Pro-Life Issues|date=|work=Federal Policies|publisher=The Christian Democratic Party|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309080339/http://www.cdp.org.au/federal-policies/pro-life-issues.html|archivedate=9 March 2012|deadurl=yes|accessdate=31 October 2011|df=dmy}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cdp.org.au/federal-policies/islam.html|title=Islam|date=|work=Federal Policies|publisher=The Christian Democratic Party|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928073533/http://www.cdp.org.au/federal-policies/islam.html|archivedate=28 September 2011|deadurl=yes|accessdate=31 October 2011|df=dmy}} === Law & Order === The CDP supports rehabilitation of criminals when possible. They seek "a wisely governed penal system that seeks to restore convicted persons where possible to good contributors to society."{{cite web|url=https://www.cdp.org.au/policy/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180508090224/https://www.cdp.org.au/policy/|archivedate=2018-05-08|title=Policy ⋆ Christian Democratic Party|date=2018-05-08|access-date=2018-05-08}} === Economy & Housing === CDP's policy on the economy is to ensure ""a healthy environment for business to start and grow". They support an adequately "remunerated job" to allow for "a balance between work and non-work times" and have an emphasis on "the financial well-being of each person in [the] community". In 2015 Nile supported the Liberal government's [[privatisation]] of electricity infrastructure, such as poles and wires.{{cite web|last=Kozaki |first=Danuta |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-03-30/public-float-considered-for-nsw-electricity-privatisation/6357882 |title=NSW Election 2015: Public float considered for NSW poles and wires privatisation, Baird |publisher=ABC News |date=2015-03-30 |accessdate=2018-05-16}}{{cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/national/nsw/nsw-premier-mike-bairds-power-sale-passes-christian-democratic-mp-fred-nile-roadblock-20150603-ghfrev.html |title=NSW Premier Mike Baird's power sale passes Christian Democratic MP Fred Nile roadblock |publisher=Smh.com.au |date=2015-06-03 |accessdate=2018-05-16}} === Education & Health === The Christian Democratic Party believe that parental input in a child's education plus writing, reading and arithmetic are the basis of a good education system. They also support Special Religious Education (SRE). CDP believes that Health Care "should be available, accessible and affordable". === Environment & Social Security === According to their 2018 policies, the CDP supports a balanced approach to both environment and social security. They seek a "good and sustainable use of the earth" and social security for "those who genuinely need it". === Employment, Immigration & Infrastructure === The CDP is for local industry and local jobs and "proactively [work] to advocate for jobs growth". Their policy on immigration reads: "Each nation needs to manage its immigration so that there is a balance of visitors and immigrants that will contribute positively to the nation. In the last several years we have seen a rise in immigration that has outpaced infrastructure and potentially affecting housing affordability''',''' health affordability, and employment declines, and a strain on the social security system resulting in community disquiet towards some new immigrants. This has the potential to change the character of the Australian society. Immigration needs to be carefully managed, taken on the advice of demographic experts and not growth economics." The Christian Democrats also support strong infrastructure programs for roads, bridges, hospitals, airports, waterways and power supplies. They state that these should be "steady and affordable" and planned for "future generations", not simply as short-term goals. ==Controversies== The party and a candidate, Peter Madden, came under intense opposition from their policies and political campaign actions by the [[Returned and Services League of Australia]] (RSL).{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/private-sydney/pulpit-choice-gives-offence-20110128-1a88u.html |title=Pulpit choice gives offence |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}} Their campaign to have the [[Sydney Mardi Gras]] banned because of, as he puts it, "the lifestyle and perversion that it promotes" saw opposition from the RSL as one of their campaign [[YouTube]] videos, which featured Madden, labelled a "battle cry", calls upon "10,000 warriors" to rally against the event and shows Madden in front of the [[Anzac War Memorial]] in [[Hyde Park, Sydney|Hyde Park]] inviting viewers to become "lions" and join him. The NSW RSL president, Don Rowe, said that returned servicemen and women and the public as a whole find it "totally offensive" that anyone would use the image of the War Memorial to make a political statement. Don Rowe said to ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'', "I am neither a supporter nor a detractor of the Mardi Gras and the RSL has no official position on it, but we totally disapprove of the use of the War Memorial in a politicised way. It is a sacred site and symbolises those Australians who made the ultimate sacrifice for this country and for our freedoms … not for someone trying to make a political stand." Peter Madden was also criticized by the [[LGBT]] community when he called for the [[Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras]] to be "moved off the streets".’{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/life/ad-puts-a-face-to-gay-marriage-issue-20110205-1ahn4.html |title=Ad puts a face to gay marriage issue |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=6 February 2011 |accessdate=14 November 2011}} and stated in an interview with [[Glenn Wheeler]] and [[Anthony Venn-Brown]] on the [[Sydney]] radio station [[2GB]][http://www.2gb.com/index2.php?option=com_newsmanager&task=view&id=8133 http://www.2gb.com/index2.php?option=com_newsmanager&task=view&id=8133] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110223084948/http://www.2gb.com/index2.php?option=com_newsmanager&task=view&id=8133 |date=23 February 2011 }} that one of the main objectives of the [[Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras]] was "recruitment".{{cite web|url=http://www.petermadden.com.au/media-releases/202-protecting-children-from-homosexual-recruitment.html |title=Protecting children from homosexual recruitment |date=26 February 2011 |accessdate=14 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425163426/http://www.petermadden.com.au/media-releases/202-protecting-children-from-homosexual-recruitment.html |archivedate=25 April 2012 |df=dmy }} ==Electoral outcomes== {{Refimprove section|date=October 2011}} The CDP has built a small but stable electoral base among conservative Roman Catholics, Eastern Orthodox and Protestants in New South Wales, particularly in the "Bible Belt" suburbs of north-western Sydney and in some country areas,{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} but the CDP has only achieved modest results in its attempts to expand its electoral base further. The party has comparable support in [[Western Australia]] (which broke away to form the Australian Christians party) but has lacked similar representation in its state parliament because its seats have higher election quotas.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} The Christian Democratic Party sees the policies of the major parties as an attack on their traditional views. [[Gordon Moyes]] (no longer a member of the party) explained, "Our Christian heritage is under attack from pagan and secularist forces, militant Islamic groups, a neo communism under a Green guise and a strident homosexual lobby that has successfully gained the support of the [[Australian Labor Party|Labor Party]], [[Australian Democrats]] and the [[Australian Greens|Greens]], and many from the left of the [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal Party]]."{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} For the 1983 federal election, the CDP formed an alliance with the Victoria-based [[Democratic Labor Party (historical)|Democratic Labor Party]]. They did not win any seats and contested subsequent elections separately.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} The Christian Democratic Party has generally had two (sometimes three) sitting Members in the Legislative Council (MLCs) at any one time. Usually, these two individuals have been [[Fred Nile]] and one other member. The 1984 NSW election saw Nile joined by former [[Liberal Party (Australia)|Liberal]] politician [[Jim Cameron (politician)|Jim Cameron]]. Cameron retired shortly after being elected, due to serious health problems, and was replaced by [[Marie Bignold]]. Nile’s wife, [[Elaine Nile]], joined her husband and Bignold after achieving election to the Legislative Council at the 1988 NSW election. Bignold subsequently had a falling out with Fred and Elaine Nile over Bignold's opposition to the Liberal Party stance on industrial relations; a policy position supported by the Niles.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} The restructuring of the Legislative Council in 1991 meant that Bignold’s seat was abolished and she was forced to an early election; but she failed in her bid for re-election. The party has been involved in [[Glenn Druery]]'s [[Minor Party Alliance]].{{cite web|last=Bormann |first=Trevor |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-09-05/bitter-dispute-erupts-over-senate-preferences-in-queensland/4939300 |title=Bitter dispute erupts over Senate preferences in Queensland |publisher=ABC News |date=2013-09-05 |accessdate=2018-05-16}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/special-features/alliance-of-micro-parties-boosts-odds-for-likes-of-one-nation-or-shooters-and-fishers-gaining-senate-spot-through-preferences/story-fnho52jp-1226713114765 |title=Alliance of micro parties boosts odds for likes of One Nation or Shooters and Fishers gaining Senate spot through preferences |publisher=Daily Telegraph |date=2013-09-05 |accessdate=2018-05-16}} ===Retirement of Elaine Nile and election of Gordon Moyes=== In August 2000, it was announced that Elaine Nile would retire due to ill health and be replaced with [[John Bradford (Australian politician)|John Bradford]], a former Liberal member of the [[Australian House of Representatives]] from [[Queensland]] who had defected to the CDP before being defeated at the 1998 Federal election.{{cite press release|url=http://www.cdp.org.au/federal-media-release/1660-john-bradford-will-replace-elaine-nile.html |title=John Bradford will replace Elaine Nile |date=29 August 2000 |work=The Christian Democratic Party |accessdate=31 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120327030743/http://www.cdp.org.au/federal-media-release/1660-john-bradford-will-replace-elaine-nile.html |archivedate=27 March 2012 |df= }} However, this fell through due to disagreements between the Fred and Elaine Nile and Bradford. Elaine Nile served until 2002, at which time she was replaced by [[Gordon Moyes]] of Sydney’s Wesley Central Mission. Moyes was elected in his own right at the 2003 NSW election.{{cite journal |author=Clune, David |title=2000 Ad |journal=Australian Journal of Politics and History |date=June 2001 |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_go1877/is_2_47/ai_n28842652/pg_5/ |accessdate=31 October 2011 |publisher=University of Queensland Press }} In 2004, Moyes suggested Nile make a bid for a Senate seat at the [[Australian federal election, 2004|2004 federal election]]. In that election, Nile achieved 2.6% of the primary vote, but narrowly missed attaining a seat. Another rival conservative party, [[Family First Party|Family First]], won a seat in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] with 1.9% and a better preference deal. With Nile's return to the NSW Legislative Council, Moyes began to question the leadership of his former party leader.{{Verify source|date=October 2011}} During the [[New South Wales legislative election, 2007]] the CDP called for a moratorium on Muslim [[immigration to Australia]], seeking to replace them with "persecuted Christians from the Middle East." Nile said the moratorium should be in place to allow a study of the effects of Muslim migration. "There has been no serious study of the potential effects upon Australia of more than 300,000 Muslims who are already here," he said. "Australians deserve a breathing space so the situation can be carefully assessed before Islamic immigration can be allowed to resume. In the meantime, Australia should extend a welcoming hand to many thousands of persecuted Christians who are presently displaced or at risk in the Middle East."{{cite news |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,21364439-2702,00.html |title=Nile wants stop to Muslim migrants |work=The Australian |date=12 March 2007 |accessdate= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070525034259/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,21364439-2702,00.html |archive-date=25 May 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Nile and another CDP candidate Allan Lotfizadeh reported receiving death threats on account of this announcement.{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,21375264-5006784,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070316075322/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0%2C20867%2C21375264-5006784%2C00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 March 2007 |title=Christian Democrats receive death threats |work=The Australian |date=13 March 2007 |accessdate= |df= }} Fred Nile was re-elected to the New South Wales Legislative Council on 24 March 2007, achieving a vote of 4.4%. This was the highest vote for the CDP since 1988. ===Battle between Nile and Moyes=== In 2007, the President of the Legislative Council, Meredith Anne Burgmann retired from public service{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/web/common.nsf/key/ArchivesLegislativeCouncilPresidentsoftheLegislativeCouncil |title=Presidents of the Legislative Council, 1856 to date |publisher=Parliament of New South Wales |date= |accessdate=19 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110314214201/https://parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/web/common.nsf/key/ArchivesLegislativeCouncilPresidentsoftheLegislativeCouncil |archivedate=14 March 2011 |df= }} and the Council sought a replacement. Tensions flared when both Moyes and Nile applied for the position. Nile subsequently withdrew his application and nominated Moyes at Moyes' behest.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} [[Peter Primrose]] was confirmed President on 8 March 2007, Moyes having received only two votes, Nile's and his own.{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/PARLMENT/hansArt.nsf/V3Key/LC20070508006 |title=Presidents of the Legislative Council vote |publisher=Parliament of New South Wales |date= |accessdate=19 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525033844/http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/PARLMENT/hansArt.nsf/V3Key/LC20070508006 |archivedate=25 May 2011 |df= }} After Nile was made Assistant Deputy President on 28 June 2007 and then Assistant President 28 November 2007, Moyes began to publicly attack Nile.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} Moyes argued that Nile's anti-homosexual, anti-abortion and anti-Muslim focus should be altered and that greater emphasis be placed on environmental issues.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} In contrast to Nile, Moyes inferred that the burden of responsibility for Islamic terrorism lay at the feet of western civilisation, the "Crusades" and the "excesses of the 'war on terrors'.{{cite web|url=http://www.gordonmoyes.com/2008/01/07/what-of-muslim-immigration-and-the-existence-of-their-schools/ |title=What of Muslim immigration and the existence of their schools |publisher=Gordon Moyes |date=7 January 2008 |accessdate=19 June 2010}} Moyes (then aged 70 years) claimed Nile (then aged 75 years) was too old and was too "committed to gaining money and status, and [...attacked...] any who disagree[d] with himself". According to Moyes, Nile was a pathetic figure who has never laughed, has no friends, is a workaholic, has no interests or hobbies, eats fast-food meals and when in Sydney attending Parliament, spends every night alone in a cheap motel in western Sydney.{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/christian-soldiers-at-war/2008/09/06/1220121593002.html |title=Christian Soldiers at War |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |author=Carly, Lisa |date=7 September 2008 |accessdate=19 June 2010}} In February 2009, Nile wrote in his monthly newsletter that he regretted allowing Moyes to take his wife's place upon her retirement "because of his disloyalty and divisive actions and his frequent support of the Greens".{{cite news|title=God's MPs in row|date=3 February 2009|page=8|work=The Daily Telegraph |location=Australia |accessdate= }} Moyes stated that the Greens were "far more Christian".{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/02/03/2480625.htm|title='Anti-Muslim, anti-gay': Party in holy war of words|work=ABC News |location=Australia |date=3 February 2009|accessdate=8 March 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2009/02/03/1233423223158.html |title=Nile calls on the power of prayer to remove a political thorn in his side|date=4 February 2009|last=Feneley|first=Rick|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=8 March 2010}} Moyes also attacked the Christian Democratic Party itself, stating that the party was a cult,{{cite web|url=http://www.gordonmoyes.com/2009/04/20/expelled-for-trying-to-be-more-christian/ |title=Expelled for trying to be more Christian |publisher=Gordon Moyes |date=20 April 2009 |accessdate=19 June 2010}} a hypocritical, anti-Christian, anti-democratic dictatorship that adhered to the values of extremist fundamentalism.{{cite web|url=http://www.gordonmoyes.com/2009/04/20/why-party-expulsions-are-self-defeating/ |title=Why Party expulsions are self defeating |publisher=Gordon Moyes |date=20 April 2009 |accessdate=19 June 2010}} Moyes claimed that the "end was nigh" for the party as there was a conspiracy to disband the party and form a new conservative Christian political party.{{cite web|url=http://www.gordonmoyes.com/2009/01/08/the-end-is-nigh/ |title=The End is Nigh |publisher=Gordon Moyes |date=8 January 2009 |accessdate=19 June 2010}} Moyes attempted to draw Nile's Parliamentary staff into the conflict by making claims that they had intimidated and bullied his own.{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/web/common.nsf/key/LCStructure |title=David Blunt: Deputy Clerk of the NSW Parliament |date=23 March 2009 |publisher=Parliament of New South Wales |accessdate=19 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101206093911/http://www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/web/common.nsf/key/LCStructure |archivedate=6 December 2010 |df=dmy }} Moyes ignored repeated warnings from the CDP management committee, claiming that they were dysfunctional. a committee of the "sad, mad, senile and aggressively ambitious."{{cite web|url=http://www.gordonmoyes.com/2009/04/17/do-cdp-members-realise-what-is-happening/ |title=Do CDP members realise what is happening |publisher=Gordon Moyes |date=17 April 2009 |accessdate=19 June 2010}} As a result, Moyes was expelled from the Christian Democratic Party in March 2009 by secret ballot of its members.{{cite news|url=http://www.cdp.org.au/download/Gordon_Moyes_Letter.pdf |title=Expulsion of Dr Moyes - Right of Appeal |date=18 March 2009 |last=Sheppard |first=Elwyn |work=The Family World News |accessdate=18 March 2009 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141213191931/http://www.cdp.org.au/download/Gordon_Moyes_Letter.pdf |archivedate=13 December 2014 |df= }}{{cite news |url=http://www.crikey.com.au/2009/04/20/nile-expells-flash-but-he-wont-be-silenced/ |work=Crikey |title=Nile expells{{sic|nolink=y}} Flash but he won’t be silenced |author=Mitchell, Alex |date=20 April 2009 |accessdate=31 October 2011 }} Moyes became an [[independent (politics)|independent]] for several months before joining the Family First Party in 2009. Moyes failed in his attempt to be re-elected at the [[New South Wales state election, 2011|2011 state election]]. ===Election of Paul Green=== [[Paul Green (Australian politician)|Paul Green]] was elected to the NSW Legislative Council at the 2011 state election. Aged 45 years at the time of this election.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} ==Members of Parliament== ===Federal=== * [[John Bradford (Australian politician)|John Bradford]] MP (1998){{spaced ndash}}representing ([[Division of McPherson|McPherson]], Qld). Bradford was elected to the [[Australian House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] in 1990 as a member of the [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal Party]]. On 7 April 1998 Bradford resigned his membership of the Liberal Party, and sat in the House as a member of the Christian Democratic Party until the [[Australian federal election, 1998|1998 federal election]]; in which he unsuccessfully contested the [[Australian Senate|Senate]] for the CDP. ===New South Wales=== * [[Fred Nile]] MLC (1981–2004; 2004–present) * [[Jim Cameron (politician)|Jim Cameron]] MLC (1984) * [[Marie Bignold]] MLC (1984–88){{ref label|Bign|1|1}} * [[Elaine Nile]] MLC (1988–2002) * [[Gordon Moyes]] MLC (2002–09){{ref label|Moye|2|2}} * [[Paul Green (Australian politician)|Paul Green]] MLC (2011–present) :{{note label|Bign|1|1}} Bignold remained in Parliament without CDP endorsement until 1991 :{{note label|Moye|2|2}} Moyes remained in Parliament without CDP endorsement as an independent ==Electoral performance== ===Senate=== {| class=wikitable style="text-align: right;" |- ! revision.comment: /* Expatriate Christians */
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}}
{{Christianity by country}} '''Christianity in [[Kuwait]]''' is a minority religion, accounting for 18%-20% of the country's population, or 650,000 - 750,000 people. Kuwait's Christians can be divided into 2 groups. The first group are Christians who are native Kuwaitis numbering approximately between 200 and 400 people.<ref name=ref/><ref name=num/> The second group, who make up the majority of Christians in Kuwait, are expatriates from various countries around the world. There are also a number of believers in Christ from a Muslim background in the country, though many are not citizens. A 2015 study estimates some 350 such Christians in the country that are ex Muslim.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Johnstone|first1=Patrick|last2=Miller|first2=Duane|title=Believers in Christ from a Muslim Background: A Global Census|journal=Interdisciplinary Journal of Research on Religion|date=2015|volume=11|page=16|url=https://www.academia.edu/16338087/Believers_in_Christ_from_a_Muslim_Background_A_Global_Census|accessdate=28 October 2015}}</ref>
==Kuwaiti Christians== Kuwait's native Christian population is diverse. There are between 259 and 400 Christian Kuwaiti citizens.<ref name=ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.refworld.org/country,,,ANNUALREPORT,KWT,,3ae6a88954,0.html |title=International Religious Freedom Report |work=[[US State Department]]|year=1999}}</ref><ref name=num>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabtimesonline.com/RSS/tabid/69/smid/414/ArticleID/147658/Default.aspx |title='Christians Enjoy Religious Freedom' |work=arabtimesonline.com |year=2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402125518/http://www.arabtimesonline.com/RSS/tabid/69/smid/414/ArticleID/147658/Default.aspx |archivedate=2 April 2015 }}</ref><ref name=rel/> In 2014, there were 259 Christian Kuwaitis residing in Kuwait.<ref name=rel>{{cite web |url=http://stat.paci.gov.kw/arabicreports/#DataTabPlace:ColumnChartEduAge |title=Nationality By Religion and Nationality|work=Government of Kuwait|language=Arabic}}</ref>
Christian Kuwaitis can be divided into 2 groups. The first group includes the earliest Kuwaiti Christians, who originated from [[Iraq]] and [[Turkey]].<ref name=num/> They have assimilated into Kuwaiti society, like their Muslim counterparts, and tend to speak Arabic with a [[Kuwaiti Arabic|Kuwaiti dialect]]; their [[Kuwaiti cuisine|food]] and [[Culture of Kuwait|culture]] are also predominantly Kuwaiti. The make up very less than roughly a quarter of Kuwait's Christian population. The rest (roughly three-quarters) of Christian Kuwaitis make up the second group. They are more recent arrivals in the 1950s and 1960s, mostly Kuwaitis of Palestinian ancestry who were forced out of [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] after 1948.<ref name=num/> There are also smaller numbers who originally hail from [[Syria]] and [[Lebanon]].<ref name=num/> This second group is not as assimilated as the first group, as their [[Levantine cuisine|food]], [[Levant#Culture|culture]], and [[Levantine Arabic|Arabic dialect]] still retain a [[Levant]] feel. However, they are just as patriotic as the former group, and tend to be proud of their adopted homeland, with many serving in the army, police, civil, and foreign service. Most of Kuwait's citizen Christians belong to 12 large families, with the Shammas (from Turkey) and the Shuhaibar (from Palestine) families being some of the more prominent ones.<ref name=num/>
Although there is a small community of Christian citizens, a law passed in 1981 prevents the naturalization of non-Muslims.<ref name=ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.refworld.org/country,,,ANNUALREPORT,KWT,,3ae6a88954,0.html |title=International Religious Freedom Report |work=[[US State Department]]|year=1999}}</ref> However, male citizens who were Christians before 1980 (and male children born to families of such citizens since that date), can transmit their citizenship to their children; however, they cannot transmit their citizenship to their spouses.<ref name=ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.refworld.org/country,,,ANNUALREPORT,KWT,,3ae6a88954,0.html |title=International Religious Freedom Report |work=[[US State Department]]|year=1999}}</ref>
Kuwait is the only [[Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf|GCC]] country besides [[Bahrain]] to have a local Christian population who hold citizenship.{{fact|date=December 2016}}
Traditionally, [[Eastern Orthodox]] Christians in Kuwait belong to the jurisdiction of [[Eastern Orthodox Patriarchate of Antioch and All the East]]. Eastern Orthodox parish in Kuwait was reorganized in 1969 by late metropolitan [[Constantine Papastephanou]] of Baghdad and Kuwait (1969-2014), who visited Kuwait on many occasions.<ref>[http://www.antiochian.org/memory-eternal-metropolitan-constantine-papastephanou Memory Eternal: Metropolitan Constantine (Papastephanou)]</ref> His successor is Metropolitan [[Ghattas Hazim]] of Baghdad and Kuwait (since 2014). His official seat remains in Baghdad, but administrative headquarters of the Archdiocese are located in Kuwait. Today, Eastern Orthodox parishes in Kuwait are administered by priests Ephrem Toumi and Filimon Saifi.<ref>[http://www.gulforthodoxchurch.org/E/GOC_E.htm Official Page of the Eastern Orthodox Archdiocese of Baghdad, Kuwait and Dependencies]</ref>
=== Notable people === * Amanuel Benjamin Ghareeb (born 1950), an important Kuwaiti priest and representative of the Evangelical Church of Kuwait.<ref name=num/>
==Expatriate Christians== [[File:Holy Family Cathedral (Kuwait).jpg|300px|thumb|Holy Family Cathedral, [[Kuwait City]].]] The denominations of both citizen and foreign Christians in Kuwait include, but are not limited to, the following:
* 140,000 Catholics in [[Kuwait]]. There is a cathedral in [[Kuwait City]], which belongs to the [[Vicariate Apostolic of Kuwait]]. The Catholic Vicariate is largely made up of Asians from India, the Philippines, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, and Pakistan, and Arab Christians from Lebanon, Egypt, Jordan, Palestine, and Syria. Maronite Christians, mostly from Lebanon, also worship at the Catholic cathedral in Kuwait City. A small group of Catholics are from Europe and the Americas. * 67,500 Orthodox Christians, at least. The [[Greek Orthodox Church]] has about 3,500 members, while the [[Armenian Orthodox Church]] has about 4,000 members. The [[Coptic Orthodox Church]] has about 60,000 members. Totals for both the [[Greek Catholic]] (Eastern Rite) Church membership and [[Indian Orthodox Church]] membership more than 60,000.The [[ Marthoma Syrian Church]],a reformed oriental orthodox church has a membership of 70,000.The [[Jacobite Syrian Orthodox Church]] has a membership of about 20,000. * The [[Anglican Church]] has about 115 members. The [[National Evangelical Church of Kuwait]] has about 15,000 members. There are also a number other Protestant denominations in the country . These denominations include the [[Seventh-day Adventist Church]]. * Other religious groups include [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church), which has a [[Ward (LDS Church)|ward]] (congregation) of approximately 300 that meets in a villa in Salmiyah.
The constitution allows for religious freedom. Many churches exist in Kuwait. Kuwait's largest cathedral is situated in the eastern part of Kuwait city.
== See also == * [[Roman Catholicism in Kuwait]] * [[Christianity in the Middle East]] * [[Christians in the Persian Gulf]] * [[Arab Christians]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== Sources == *[http://www.catholic-church.org/kuwait/christians_in_kuwait.htm] *[http://www.win1040.com/countries/kuwait.htm] *[https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71425.htm] *[http://www.iocq8.org/]
==External links== * [http://www.gulforthodoxchurch.org/E/GOC_E.htm Official Website of the Eastern Orthodox Archdiocese of Baghdad, Kuwait and Dependencies]

revision.comment: /* External links */
revision.text:
{{Infobox newspaper |name = ''Der Blatt'' |image = <!-- Commented out: [[Image:Der Blatt.png|175px]] --> |caption = The front page of the September 15, 2006 edition |type = Weekly [[newspaper]] |format = [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|Tabloid]] |foundation = 2000 |owners = [[Milech Deutch]] |headquarters = [[Williamsburg, Brooklyn|Williamsburg]], NY |circulation = 30,000{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} |website = }} {{Yiddish Journalism}} '''''Der Blatt''''' ({{lang-yi|'''דער בּלאַט'''}}, En. ''The Page'' or ''The Newspaper'') is a weekly Yiddish newspaper published in [[New York City]] by [[Satmar (Hasidic dynasty)|Satmar]] [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidim]].
==History== ''Der Blatt'' was established in 2000, as a direct result of the [[Satmar (Hasidic dynasty)#Satmar succession feud|Satmar succession feud]]. Prior to that time there was only one Satmar newspaper, ''[[Der Yid]]''. In the dispute over the succession, ''Der Yid'' came under the control of the supporters of Rabbi [[Zalman Teitelbaum]]. This left the supporters of his rival, Rabbi [[Aaron Teitelbaum]], without a platform for [[communication]] and [[public relations]], prompting them to establish a newspaper of their own. The resulting publication, ''Der Blatt'', closely retains the basic style of ''Der Yid'' but promotes Rabbi Aaron rather than Rabbi Zalman as the legitimate successor of the previous [[rebbe]]. The publication adheres to a strict interpretation of [[Tzniut]] that prohibits photographs of women on its pages. Der Blatt follows Satmar's [[Anti Zionist]] stance.
== See also == * ''[[Der Yid]]'' * [[Kindline (magazine)|Kindline]]
== External links == * [http://www.derbay.org/publications.html Yiddish Publications]
{{Satmar (Hasidic dynasty)}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Blatt, Der}} [[Category:Newspapers published in Brooklyn]] [[Category:Jewish newspapers published in the United States]] [[Category:Yiddish-language newspapers published in the United States]] [[Category:Weekly newspapers published in the United States]] [[Category:Satmar (Hasidic dynasty)]] [[Category:Publications established in 2000]] [[Category:Jews and Judaism in Brooklyn]] [[Category:Non-English-language newspapers published in New York (state)]] [[Category:Yiddish culture in New York City]] [[Category:2000 establishments in New York (state)]]

revision.comment: Reverted to revision 849743323 by [[Special:Contributions/47.34.161.246|47.34.161.246]] ([[User talk:47.34.161.246|talk]]): SPA edits, POV issues. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
'''Doomsday cult''' is an expression used to describe [[cult]]s who believe in [[apocalypticism]] and [[millenarianism]], and can refer both to groups that predict [[disaster]], and to those that attempt to bring it about.{{cite book | last =Jenkins | first =Phillip | title = Mystics and Messiahs: Cults and New Religions in American History | publisher =[[Oxford University Press]] [[United States|USA]] | year =2000 | pages =216, 222 | id = | isbn = 0-19-514596-8}} The expression was first used by sociologist [[John Lofland (sociologist)|John Lofland]] in his 1966 study of a group of members of the [[Unification Church of the United States]] in [[California]], ''[[Doomsday Cult: A Study of Conversion, Proselytization, and Maintenance of Faith]]''. A classic study of a group with cataclysmic predictions had previously been performed by [[Leon Festinger]] and other researchers, and was published in his book ''[[When Prophecy Fails|When Prophecy Fails: A Social and Psychological Study of a Modern Group that Predicted the Destruction of the World]]''.{{cite book | last =Spilka | first =Bernard | title =The Psychology of Religion: An Empirical Approach | publisher =Guilford Press | year =2003 | id = | isbn = 1-57230-901-6 | page =356}}"The classic study by Festinger and his colleagues was titled ''When Prophecy Fails''."{{cite book | last =Goodwin | first =C. James | title =Research in Psychology: Methods and Design | publisher =J. Wiley | year =1998 | id = | isbn = 0-471-19986-9 | page =376}}"To learn more about this classic study of what happens when prophecy fails..." Referring to his study, Festinger and later other researchers have attempted to explain the commitment of members to their associated doomsday cult, even after the prophecies of their leader have turned out to be false. Festinger explained this phenomenon as part of a coping mechanism called dissonance reduction, a form of [[rationalization (making excuses)|rationalization]]. Members often dedicate themselves with renewed vigor to the group's cause after a failed prophecy, and rationalize with explanations such as a belief that their actions forestalled the disaster, or a belief in the leader when the date for disaster is postponed. Some researchers believe that the use of the term by the government and the news media can lead to a [[self-fulfilling prophecy]], in which actions by authorities reinforces the apocalyptic beliefs of the group, which in turn can inspire further controversial actions. Group leaders have themselves objected to comparisons between one group and another, and parallels have been drawn between the concept of a self-fulfilling prophecy and the theory of a [[deviancy amplification spiral]]. == Etymology == The term "doomsday cult" was first used in the title of a 1966 scholarly study of a group of [[Unification Church]] members by [[John Lofland (sociologist)|John Lofland]], entitled: ''[[Doomsday Cult: A Study of Conversion, Proselytization, and Maintenance of Faith]]''.{{cite book | last =Lofland | first =John | title =Doomsday Cult: A Study of Conversion, Proselytization, and Maintenance of Faith | publisher =[[Prentice-Hall]] | year =1966 | isbn = 978-0-8290-0095-5|doi=}} Lofland published his findings in 1964 as a doctoral thesis entitled: "The World Savers: A Field Study of Cult Processes," and in 1966 in book form by [[Prentice-Hall]].[http://hirr.hartsem.edu/ency/conversion.htm Conversion], [http://hirr.hartsem.edu/ency/Unification.htm Unification Church], ''Encyclopedia of Religion and Society'', Hartford Institute for Religion Research, [[Hartford Seminary]] It is considered to be one of the most important and widely cited studies of the process of [[religious conversion]], and one of the first modern sociological studies of a [[new religious movement]].''Introduction to New and Alternative Religions in America: African diaspora traditions and other American innovations'', Volume 5 of Introduction to New and Alternative Religions in America, W. Michael Ashcraft, Greenwood Publishing Group, 2006 {{ISBN|0-275-98717-5}}, {{ISBN|978-0-275-98717-6}}, page 180''Exploring New Religions'', Issues in contemporary religion, George D. Chryssides, Continuum International Publishing Group, 2001 {{ISBN|0-8264-5959-5}}, {{ISBN|978-0-8264-5959-6}} page 1 [[James Richardson (sociologist)|James Richardson]] writes in the ''Encyclopedia of Religion and Society'' that after the publication of Lofland's work, "The term ''doomsday cult'' has become a part of everyday parlance, used by the media to refer to apocalyptic religious groups."{{cite book | last =Swatos | first =William H. | author2 =[[James Richardson (sociologist)|James Richardson]], article: "Doomsday Cult" | title =Encyclopedia of Religion and Society | publisher =Rowman Altamira | year =1998 | id = | isbn = 0-7619-8956-0 | page =142}}[http://kingsvillerecord.our-hometown.com/news/2009-12-16/Editorial/Exploring_the_climate_of_doom.html Exploring the climate of doom] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120423123818/http://kingsvillerecord.our-hometown.com/news/2009-12-16/Editorial/Exploring_the_climate_of_doom.html |date=April 23, 2012 }}, Rich Lowry, 2009-12-19 'The phrase “doomsday cult” entered our collective vocabulary after John Lofland published his 1966 study, “Doomsday Cult: A Study of Conversion, Proselytization, and Maintenance of Faith.” Lofland wrote about the Unification Church.' == Psychological studies == {{See also|When Prophecy Fails}} A [[psychology|psychological]] study by Festinger, Riecken, and Schachter found that people turned to a cataclysmic [[world view]] after they had repeatedly failed to find meaning in mainstream movements.{{cite book | last =Pargament | first =Kenneth I. | author-link= Kenneth Pargament| title =The Psychology of Religion and Coping: Theory, Research, Practice | publisher =Guilford Press | year =1997 | pages =150–153, 340, section: "Compelling Coping in a Doomsday Cult" | id = | isbn = 1-57230-664-5}} [[Leon Festinger]] and his colleagues had observed members of the group for several months, and recorded their conversations both prior to and after a failed prophecy from their charismatic leader.{{cite book | last =Stangor | first =Charles | title =Social Groups in Action and Interaction | publisher =Psychology Press | year =2004 | pages =42–43: "When Prophecy Fails" | id = | isbn =1-84169-407-X }} The group had organized around a belief system which foretold that a majority of the [[Western Hemisphere]] would be destroyed by a cataclysmic flood on December 21, 1955.{{cite book | last =Newman | first =Dr. David M. | title =Sociology: Exploring the Architecture of Everyday Life | publisher =Pine Forge Press | year =2006 | id = | isbn = 1-4129-2814-1 | page =86}}{{cite book | last =Petty | first =Richard E. |author2=John T. Cacioppo | title =Attitudes and Persuasion: Classic and Contemporary Approaches | publisher =Westview Press | year =1996 | id = | isbn =0-8133-3005-X | page =139: "Effect of Disconfirming an Important Belief" }} Their work was later published in the book ''[[When Prophecy Fails|When Prophecy Fails: A Social and Psychological Study of a Modern Group that Predicted the Destruction of the World]]''.{{cite book | last =Festinger | first =Leon | authorlink =Leon Festinger |author2=Henry W. Riecken |author3=[[Stanley Schachter]] | title = When Prophecy Fails: A Social and Psychological Study of a Modern Group that Predicted the Destruction of the World | publisher =University of Minnesota Press | year =1956 | url =http://www.whenprophecyfails.org/ | id = | isbn = 1-59147-727-1}} [[Social science|Social scientists]] have found that while some group members will leave after the date for a doomsday prediction by the leader has passed uneventfully, others actually feel their belief and commitment to the group strengthened. Often when a group's doomsday prophecies or predictions fail to come true, the group leader will simply set a new date for impending doom, or predict a different type of catastrophe on a different date.{{cite book | last =Snow | first =Robert L. | title =[[Deadly Cults|Deadly Cults: The Crimes of True Believers]] | publisher =Praeger/Greenwood | year =2003 | pages =70, 79, 108, 111 | id = | isbn = 0-275-98052-9}} Niederhoffer and Kenner say: "When you have gone far out on a limb and so many people have followed you, and there is much "[[sunk cost]]," as economists would say, it is difficult to admit you have been wrong."{{cite book | last =Niederhoffer | first =Victor |author2=Laurel Kenner | title =Practical Speculation | publisher =[[John Wiley and Sons]] | year =2004 | pages =117–118 | id = | isbn =0-471-44306-9 }} In ''Experiments With People: Revelations from Social Psychology'', Abelson, Frey and Gregg explain this further: "...continuing to proselytize on behalf of a doomsday cult whose prophecies have been disconfirmed, although it makes little logical sense, makes plenty of psychological sense if people have already spent months proselytizing on the cult's behalf. Persevering allows them to avoid the embarrassment of how wrong they were in the first place."{{cite book | last =Abelson | first =Robert P. |author2=Kurt P. Frey|author3=Aiden P. Gregg | title =Experiments With People: Revelations from Social Psychology | publisher =Routledge | year =2003 | pages =64–65 | id = | isbn = 0-8058-2897-4}} The common-held belief in a catastrophic event occurring on a future date can have the effect of ingraining followers with a sense of uniqueness and purpose.{{cite book | last =Reynolds | first =Michael |author2=Russ Vince|author3=Joseph A. Raelin|author4=M. Ann Welsh|author5=Gordon E. Dehler|author6=Ann Cunliffe|author7=Mark Easterby-Smith | title =Organizing Reflection | publisher =Ashgate Publishing, Ltd. | year =2004 | id = | isbn = 0-7546-3747-6 | page =74}} In addition, after a failed prophecy members may attempt to explain the outcome through [[rationalization (making excuses)|rationalization]] and [[Cognitive dissonance|dissonance]] reduction.{{cite book | last =Albarracin | first =Dolores |author2=Blair T. Johnson|author3=Mark P. Zanna|author4=Icek Ajzen|author5=John N. Bassili|author6=Pablo Brinol | title =The Handbook Of Attitudes | publisher =Routledge | year =2005 | id = | isbn = 0-8058-4493-7 | page =227: "Dissonance Reduction"}}{{cite book | last =Kim | first =Min-Sun | title =Non-Western Perspectives on Human Communication: Implications for Theory and Practice | publisher =Sage Publications Inc | year =2002 | pages =75–76 | id = | isbn = 0-7619-2351-9}} Explanations may include stating that the group members had misinterpreted the leader's original plan, that the cataclysmic event itself had been postponed to a later date by the leader, or that the activities of the group itself had forestalled disaster. In the case of the Festinger study, when the prophecy of a cataclysmic flood was proved false, the members pronounced that their faith in God had prevented the event. They then proceeded to attempt to convert new members with renewed strength. In his book ''Politeia: Visions of the Just Society'', Eric Carlton debates whether or not the term is appropriate to describe these types of groups.{{cite book | last =Carlton | first =Eric | title =Politeia: Visions of the Just Society | publisher =Fairleigh Dickinson University Press | year =2006 | pages =23, 55–56 | id = | isbn = 0-8386-4102-4}} Carlton writes that the event is only seen as a "doomsday" for the "wicked and unrepentant," whereas members of the group itself often regard it as a "day of deliverance," or a "renewal of the world." He regards these groups as "the ultimate in exclusivity," and while the future will be bleak for nonbelievers due to an unforeseen [[Doomsday event|cataclysm]], members of the group are promised existence in a new [[utopia]]. == Media coverage == In ''Globalisation and the Future of Terrorism'', Brynjar Lia notes that "Doomsday cults are nothing new," but also states that they are "relatively few."{{cite book | last =Lia | first =Brynjar | title =Globalisation and the Future of Terrorism: Patterns and Predictions | publisher =Routledge | year =2005 | pages =165–169 | id = | isbn = 0-7146-5261-X}} In ''Mystics and Messiahs'', Jenkins writes that as a result of events between 1993 and 1997 including the [[Waco Siege]] involving the Branch Davidians, violence involving the [[Order of the Solar Temple]], Aum Shinrikyo's [[sarin gas attack on the Tokyo subway]], and the [[Heaven's Gate (religious group)|Heaven's Gate]] incident, "Reporting on so-called doomsday cults became a mainstay of the media, just as satanic cults had been a decade before." Jenkins regards the Order of the Solar Temple as more of an example of [[organized crime]] than a doomsday cult. In ''Yakuza: Japan's Criminal Underworld'', the authors also make a comparison to organized crime, writing that Aum Shinrikyo "...often resembled a profit-hungry racketeering gang more than a fanatic doomsday cult."{{cite book | last =Kaplan | first =David E. |author2=Alec Dubro | title =Yakuza: Japan's Criminal Underworld | publisher =University of California Press | year =2003 | id = | isbn = 0-520-21562-1 | page =208}} In [[James R. Lewis (scholar)|James R. Lewis]]' ''The Order of the Solar Temple'', he writes that the media made use of the term doomsday cult to characterize the movement, though former members and outsiders did not know what kind of event would occur.{{cite book | last =Lewis | first =James R. | authorlink =James R. Lewis (scholar) | title =The Order of the Solar Temple: The Temple of Death | publisher =Ashgate Publishing, Ltd. | year =2006 | id = | isbn = 0-7546-5285-8 | page =96}} Some see the use of the term itself as a [[self-fulfilling prophecy]], where the characterization of being called a doomsday cult may actually affect the outcome of violent events related to the group. The ''Canadian Security Intelligence Service Report on Doomsday Religious Cults'' reported:{{cite book | last =Kaplan | first =Jeffrey | title =Millennial Violence: Past, Present and Future | publisher =Routledge | year =2000 | pages =53–61, 114, 135, 228–229 | id = | isbn = 0-7146-5294-6}}"Doomsday Religious Movements", ''PERSPECTIVES'', a [[Canadian Security Intelligence Service]] publication, Report # 2000/03, December 18, 1999. [http://www.csis-scrs.gc.ca/pblctns/prspctvs/200003-eng.asp available online] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081008080703/http://www.csis-scrs.gc.ca/pblctns/prspctvs/200003-eng.asp |date=October 8, 2008 }}, last updated November 1, 2000.
Sanctions applied by authorities are often interpreted by a movement as hostile to its existence, which reinforces their apocalyptic beliefs and leads to further withdrawal, mobilization and deviant actions, and which in turn elicits heavier sanctions by authorities. This unleashes a spiral of amplification, as each action amplifies each action, and the use of violence is facilitated as the group believes this will ultimately actualize its doomsday scenario."
[[Eileen Barker]] has compared these concepts to the notion of a deviancy amplification spiral in the media and its effects on [[new religious movement]]s, and James Richardson has also discussed this effect.{{cite web|last=Barker |first=Eileen |authorlink=Eileen Barker |title=Introducing New Religious Movements |work=London School of Economics and Political Science |publisher=Fathom: the source for online learning |year=2002 |url=http://www.fathom.com/feature/121938/ |accessdate=2007-11-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014065725/http://www.fathom.com/feature/121938/ |archivedate=2007-10-14 |df= }} In the case of the [[Concerned Christians]], use of the term "doomsday cult" as a characterization of the group served as a justification for deportation of its members by the [[Israel]]i government.{{cite book | last =Gorenberg | first =Gershom | title =The End of Days: Fundamentalism and the Struggle for the Temple Mount | publisher =[[Simon & Schuster]] | year =2000 | id = | isbn = 0-7432-1621-0 | page =217}}{{cite book | last =Sennott | first =Charles M. | title =The Body and the Blood | publisher =Public Affairs | year =2001 | id = | isbn = 1-891620-95-9 | page =40}} In the book ''The Copycat Effect: How the Media and Popular Culture Trigger the Mayhem in Tomorrow's Headlines'', author Loren L. Coleman discusses the effect the media can have on the seemingly innocuous intentions of a French doomsday cult.{{cite book | last =Coleman | first =Loren L. | title =The Copycat Effect: How the Media and Popular Culture Trigger the Mayhem in Tomorrow's Headlines | publisher =[[Simon & Schuster]] | year =2004 | pages =88–89: "Cultic Copycats" | id = | isbn = 1-4165-0554-7}} On September 5, 2002, Arnaud Mussy told his followers based in [[Nantes, France]] to look forward to voyagers from [[Venus]] who would collect them before the end of the world on October 24, 2002. Though Mussy denied any plans for a [[mass suicide]], both police and the media drew parallels to the Order of the Solar Temple. In ''Apocalypse Observed'', authors Hall, Schuyler and Trinh discuss the effect the media had on the events surrounding the Order of the Solar Temple group.{{cite book | last =Hall | first =John R. |author2=Philip Daniel Schuyler|author3=Sylvaine Trinh | title =Apocalypse Observed: Religious Movements and the State in North America, Europe and Japan | publisher =Routledge | year =2000 | id = | isbn = 0-415-19277-3 | page =132}} ==Examples== The most prominent example of doomsday cult is various Christian churches and organisations who have been predicting the end of the world[[List of dates predicted for apocalyptic events#Religious-related predictions|List of dates predicted for apocalyptic events]]{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=January 2018}}[https://www.jw.org/en/publications/magazines/g201511/when-will-world-end-bible-prophecy/ THE BIBLE’S VIEWPOINT: The End of the World] or doomsday which is based on biblical verses.[http://churchandstate.org.uk/2016/11/the-end-of-the-world-will-begin-in-2017-christians-say-and-its-predicted-in-the-bible/ ''The end of the world will begin in 2017, Christians say – and it’s predicted in the Bible''][https://www.ucg.org/the-good-news/the-end-of-the-world-what-does-the-bible-say The End of the World: What Does the Bible Say?][https://www.jw.org/en/bible-teachings/questions/end-times-prophecy-sign/ What Is the Sign of “the Last Days,” or “End Times”?] Some of the major doomsday events in [[Christian mythology]] are: [[End time#Christianity|End time]], [[Second Coming]], [[Last Judgment]], [[Great Tribulation]], [[Rapture]] among others. However the various sects of Christianity vary widely in their interpretations and importance given to these elements in day-to-day practice; Christian doomsday cults such as the [[Branch Davidians]] usually place a very strong emphasis on the imminence of the [[Apocalypse]] and the personal importance of cult members to its initiation or course, with their interpretations of the [[Book of Revelation]] typically differing strongly or being completely different to that of mainstream branches of Christianity. == References == {{reflist|40em}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Cults]] [[Category:Apocalyptic groups]] [[Category:Unification Church neologisms]] [[Category:Words coined in the 1960s]]

revision.text:
'''''Guruwari''''' or "totem design" or "seed power" is an idea that appears in the [[Warlpiri language]] of the culture of [[Indigenous Australians|indigenous Australian peoples]]. Guruwari is intimately associated with [[Dreaming (spirituality)|The Dreaming]].
Guruwari also refers to the energetic "pattern" in the Aboriginal concept that states that every activity or process leaves an "energetic residue" in the ground, similar to plants leaving an image of themselves in the shape of the seeds. It is, consequently, an important part of the fields and it imprints its metaphysical, deep meaning.
==References== * [[Munn, Nancy D.]] (1984). ''The Transformation Of Subjects Into Objects in Walbiri and Pitjantjartjara Myths''. In: M. Charlesworth, H. Morphy, D. Bell and K. Maddock, Eds. ''Religion in Aboriginal Australia: An Anthology.'' St. Lucia, Queensland: [[University of Queensland Press]]. * Stanislav Grof (2006) . ''When the Impossible Happens: Adventures in Non-Ordinary Realities.''
[[Category:Australian Aboriginal mythology]]

revision.text:
[[File:HYANG.gif|thumb|Calligraphy [[Javanese Script]] "Hyang"]]
[[File:Acintya Bali.jpg|thumb|220px|[[Acintya]], Sang Hyang Widhi as supreme [[God]] in [[Balinese Hinduism]].]]
A '''Hyang''' ([[Kawi language|Kawi]], [[Javanese language|Javanese]], [[Sundanese language|Sundanese]], and [[Balinese language|Balinese]]) is an unseen [[spiritual entity]] that has [[supernatural]] power in ancient [[Mythology of Indonesia|Indonesian mythology]].<ref name="Sang Hyang Widhi">{{Cite news|url=http://www.mantrahindu.com/penjelasan-lengkap-acintya-sang-hyang-widhi-sang-hyang-tunggal/|title=Penjelasan Lengkap Acintya (Sang Hyang Widhi atau Sang Hyang Tunggal) - Mantra Hindu Bali|date=2015-12-17|work=Mantra Hindu Bali|access-date=2018-07-13|language=id-ID}}</ref> This [[spirit]] can be either [[divinity|divine]] or [[ancestral]]. The reverence for this spiritual entity can be found in [[Sunda Wiwitan]], [[Kejawen]], and [[Balinese Hinduism]]. In the modern [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]] this term tends to be associated with [[gods]], [[devata]], or [[God]].<ref name="Sang Hyang Widhi"/> The realm where the hyangs reside is called ''kahyangan''; the abode of gods, now a synonym for [[svarga]] or [[heaven]] in modern [[Bahasa Indonesia]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://kbbi.web.id/kahyangan|title=Arti kata kahyangan - Kamus Besar Bahasa Indonesia (KBBI) Online|last=Setiawan|first=Ebta|website=kbbi.web.id|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref>
[[Balinese Hinduism|Hindu Balinese]] spiritualism describes hyang as a venerated spiritual existence, that deserves a special reverence. Hyang is commonly described as a sacred and luminous personal form. It is the name for a spiritual existence that has supernatural powers, portrayed like the sun in a dream. His arrival in a person's life gives contentment without a pause for a long time, which is indistinguishable between dream and reality. Indonesians generally recognize this term to refer the cause of beauty, the cause of all existence (creator), or simply to refer God.<ref name="Sang Hyang Widhi"/>
== Origin == The term "hyang" now widely associated with [[Balinese Hinduism]] developed in ancient [[Java]] and [[Bali]] more than a millennium ago. However this term actually has an older origin, it has its root in the indigenous [[animism]] and [[dynamism (metaphysics)|dynamism]] beliefs of [[Austronesian people]] that inhabit the [[Indonesian archipelago]]. Native pre-Hindu Buddhist and pre-Islamic Indonesians venerated and revered [[ancestor|ancestral spirits]], they also believed that some [[spirits]] may inhabit certain places such as large trees, stones, forests, mountains, or any sacred places. The "hyang" concept indigenously developed in the archipelago and not considered to have originated from [[India]]n [[dharmic religions]].
Before the adoption of [[Hinduism]], [[Buddhism]] and [[Islam]], the natives of the Indonesian archipelago believed in powerful but unseen spiritual entities that can be both benevolent or malevolent. They also believed that the deceased ancestor is not gone away or disappeared completely. The ancestral spirit may gain god-like spiritual power and remain involved in their offspring's worldly affairs. That is why the veneration and reverence to honor ancestors is an important element in the belief system of native ethnic groups, such as [[Nias]], [[Dayak people|Dayak]], [[Toraja]], [[Papuan peoples|Papuan]] ethnic groups, as well as many [[ethnic groups in Indonesia]].
In ancient [[Sundanese people|Sundanese]], [[Javanese people|Javanese]], and [[Balinese people|Balinese]] society, this unseen spiritual entity is identified as "hyang". These ancestral divine spirits are believed to inhabit high places, such as [[mountains]], hills, and [[volcanoes]]. These mountainous regions are considered sacred realms, as the abode of gods and the resting place for the [[soul]] of the ancestors.
Several ancient Indonesian inscriptions dated from Hindu-Buddhist period (8th to 15th century), mentioned ''hyang'' either as the name of sanctuary or the name of deity revered in that [[Candi of Indonesia|temple]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.id/books?id=7cd2Ha7fT90C&pg=PA144&dq=sang+hyang+candi&hl=id&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjD7Mbm9ZrcAhWEs48KHcxABtYQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=sang%20hyang%20candi&f=false|title=The Javanese Candi: Function and Meaning|last=Soekmono|first=R.|date=1995|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9004102159|language=en}}</ref>
== Etymology == [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Sang Hyang dans TMnr 60052123.jpg|thumb|right|The sacred [[Balinese dance]] [[Sanghyang]] Dedari involved girls being possessed by hyangs.]] In [[Sundanese language|Sundanese]], the term ''"nga-hyang"'' means "disappear" or "unseen". It is suggested that the word "hyang" has linguistic relation with the [[Malay language|Malay]] word: ''"hilang"'' which means "disappear". In its development, the term "hyang" become the root word for many terms that still known and used in modern Indonesian: * '''Reverence'''. If the word "hyang" is attached with prefixes attribute ''Sang-, Dang-, Ra-''; to form the word ''Sanghyang, Danghyang'', or ''Rahyang'', it is meant to honor or revere [[gods]] or the deceased ancestors. For example, [[Dewi Sri|Sanghyang Sri Pohaci]] and [[Acintya|Sang Hyang Widhi]]<ref name="Sang Hyang Widhi"/> refer to [[gods]], while the stylized name [[Niskala Wastu Kancana|Rahyang Dewa Niskala]] refer to the name of late king of [[Sunda kingdom]]. The term ''Danghyang'' or ''Danyang'' is refer to the guardian spirits of certain sacred or haunted places. The name of [[Srivijaya]]n empire founder, [[Dapunta Hyang Sri Jayanasa]], also contained the name "hyang" which suggested that he possessed supernatural power. * '''Place'''. ''Kahyangan'' — later ''kayangan'', from the word ''ka-hyang-an'' — is the realm where hyangs resides. Because of the belief that hyang prefer high places, some mountainous regions is considered as the abode of hyang. For example, [[Parahyangan]] refer to mountainous region of [[West Java]]. Originated from combined words ''para-hyang-an''; ''para'' indicate plural, while the suffix ''-an'' shows the place, so Parahyangan means the abode of hyangs. The term kahyangan is also used as the type of [[Pura (Balinese temple)|Pura]] or Balinese temple. ''Pura kahyangan jagad'' is Balinese temple that located in mountainous region as the counterparts of ''pura segara''; Balinese temple located by the sea.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://new.babadbali.com/category/pura/daftar-pura/pura-kahyangan-jagat/|title=Pura Kahyangan Jagat – Babadbali|website=new.babadbali.com|language=id|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref> [[Dieng Plateau]] in [[Central Java]] also shared the same origin, it is from the combined words ''di-hyang'' which also means "hyang's place". * '''Activity'''. The word ''sembahyang'' in [[Malay language|Malay]] is [[synonym]]ous with the Islamic [[salat]] ritual.<ref>{{cite web |title="sembahyang" - Maklumat Kata |url=http://prpm.dbp.gov.my/Cari1?keyword=sembahyang |website=Pusat Rujukan Persuratan Melayu |publisher=[[Dewan Bahasa dan Pustaka]] Malaysia |accessdate=13 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref> It actually originated from the combined word ''sembah-hyang'' which means "worship the hyang".<ref name="KBBI2">{{cite web| title=Sembahyang | publisher= Kamus Besar Bahasa Indonesia (KBBI)| url=http://kbbi.web.id/sembahyang | language = Indonesian| accessdate = 28 May 2015}}</ref> The [[Balinese dance|Balinese]] ''[[Sanghyang]] Dedari'' sacred dance involved some pre-pubescent girls dances in [[trance]] condition. Through complex rituals to summons the hyangs spirits, it is believed that the spirits [[Spirit possession|possessed]] the girls and made them unconsciously dance with complex movements.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnnindonesia.com/hiburan/20170128232759-241-189763/jejak-terakhir-sanghyang-dedari-tari-sakral-di-bali|title=Jejak Terakhir Sanghyang Dedari, Tari Sakral di Bali|last=Khoiri|first=Agniya|work=hiburan|access-date=2018-07-13|language=id}}</ref> ''Sanghyang Jaran'' is Balinese name for ''[[Kuda Lumping]]'' dance that also involving performer being [[trance|entranced]] by spirit.
== Characteristics == Hyang are said to only move in straight lines. Accordingly, traditional Balinese buildings have a wall called an '''{{visible anchor|aling-aling}}''' just inside the doorway, which keeps the spirits out because they only move in straight lines, and hence bounce off.<ref>[http://www.bali-travel-life.com/bali-religion.html Bali Religion] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704121228/http://www.bali-travel-life.com/bali-religion.html |date=2010-07-04 }}</ref> Similar walls can be seen at the entrance of some Javanese cemeteries. Parallel beliefs are found in other spiritual traditions, as in British [[corpse road]]s. ==See also== {{Div col}} *[[Aitu]] *[[Anito]] *[[Apsara]], divine celestial maiden *[[Atua]] *[[Devata]], deities, divine beings or lesser gods in Hindu-Buddhist belief *[[Diwata]], similar concept in the Philippines *[[Divinity]] *[[Hanitu]] *[[Hantu demon|Hantu]] *[[Kaharingan]] *[[Kami]], similar concept in Japanese [[Shinto]] faith *[[Kupua]] *[[Moai]] *[[Nuku-mai-tore]] *[[Soul dualism]] *[[Taotao Mona]] *[[Tiki]] *[[Yōkai]] {{div col end}}
== References == {{reflist}} {{refbegin}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100704121228/http://www.bali-travel-life.com/bali-religion.html Bali Religion] {{refend}}
{{Names of God}}
